Event.name: Reading_activity
Event.definition:
<def-root>A <fen>Reader</fen> visually examines a <fen>Text</fen>, typically in a linear order, to understand its content. In place of the <fen>Text</fen>, a <fen>Topic</fen> may be mentioned.
<ex><fex name="Reader">She</fex> ca n't <t>read</t> . <fex name="Text">INI</fex></ex> <ex><fex name="Reader">They</fex> <t>read</t> <fex name="Text">the bible</fex> <fex name="Frequency">nightly</fex> .</ex> <ex><fex name="Reader">I</fex> 've <t>read</t> <fex name="Topic">about you</fex> !</ex>
<ex></ex> This frame differs from the Reading_perception frame, which obligatorily focuses on the perceptual and cognitive interpretive aspects of reading; unlike Reading_activity, targets in Reading_perception require explicit mention of the <fen>Text</fen> being examined. While Reading_activity is broad enough to cover the same circumstances as Reading_perception, it also covers situations where reading is contrasted merely with another task or leisure activity, when reading is considered generically, and when the <fen>Topic</fen> unifying the reading activity replaces mention of a <fen>Text</fen>. <ex></ex> Additionally, this frame differs from Hearsay in that Reading_activity is focused on what the <fen>Reader</fen> is agentively doing, whereas in Hearsay, the focus is on what the Hearer knows and how they know it. As a result, most valences are unambiguous: full clause complements for the Message point to the Hearsay frame, while <fen>Text</fen> or lack of any complement indicates the Reading_activity frame. The only overlap is in the case of <fen>Topic</fen>, where the frames can be still distinguished by factivity of the <fen>Topic</fen>. In other words, read.v used in the Hearsay frame, just like hear.v in the Hearsay frame, when used with a <fen>Topic</fen>, indicates clearly that there is some specific fact related to the <fen>Topic</fen> that the reader or hearer now knows and understands. Thus the first and second of the following sentences belong to Hearsay, the last to Reading_activity: <ex>Yes, I <t>read</t> about how you won teacher of the year .</ex> <ex>I just <t>read</t> about the accident .</ex> <ex></ex> <ex>I was <t>reading</t> about dinosaurs all day.</ex>
</def-root>

Arg.name: Reader
Arg.definition: <def-root>The one who examines a <fen>Text</fen> to understand it.</def-root>

Arg.name: Sought_phenomenon
Arg.definition: <def-root>A particular characteristic or thing that the <fen>Reader</fen> intends to process. <t>Read</t> <fex name="Text">Chapter 7</fex> <fex name="Sought_phenomenon">only for the major concepts.</fex>.</def-root>

Arg.name: Manner
Arg.definition: <def-root>Any description of the reading event that implicates details of how the event unfolds or is carried out (e.g. "the same way"); additionally used for descriptions of the <fen>Reader</fen> that also affect the event (e.g. "eagerly").</def-root>

Arg.name: Means
Arg.definition: <def-root>An act that allows the <fen>Reader</fen> to read in the specified manner. <ex>I <t>skimmed</t> the book <fex name="Mns">by reading just the section headings and the first sentences after</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Purpose
Arg.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Purpose</fen> is the reason for which the <fen>Reader</fen> reads the <fen>Text</fen>.</def-root>

Arg.name: Time
Arg.definition: <def-root>When the reading event takes place. <ex>Charlie often <t>reads</t> the newspaper <fex name="Time">at night</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Place
Arg.definition: <def-root>Where the reading event takes place. <ex>Surprisingly, few of the students <t>read</t> much at all <fex name="Place">in the designated reading rooms</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Circumstances
Arg.definition: <def-root>Circumstances describe the state of the world (at a particular time and place) which is specifically independent of the event itself and any of its participants.</def-root>

Arg.name: Topic
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The idea that an implicit <fen>Text</fen> or texts focuses on.
<ex>I love <t>reading</t> <fex name="top">about history</fex> .</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Frequency
Arg.definition:
<def-root>An assessment of how many iterations of (the specified kind of) reading occur per time.
<ex>I do n't <t>read</t> <fex name="Freq">often</fex> ; but when I do ...</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: read.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: look at and comprehend the meaning of (written or printed matter) by interpreting the characters or symbols of which it is composed.
